definitions.definition: the part of a plant that grows under the ground and takes in water and minerals that it sends to the rest of the plant

examples.text: deep spreading roots
Tree roots can cause damage to buildings.
I pulled the plant up by the roots *(= including the roots)*.
root vegetables/crops *(= plants whose roots you can eat, such as carrots)*
Good soil promotes strong root growth.
Root tips die quickly when exposed to light and air.

definitions.definition: the part of a hair, tooth, nail or tongue that attaches it to the rest of the body

examples.text: hair that is blonde at the ends and dark at the roots

definitions.definition: the main cause of something, such as a problem or difficult situation
definitions.sensetop: root of somethingat the root of something

examples.text: Money, or love of money, is said to be **the root of all evil**.
We have to get to **the root of the problem**.
What lies at the root of his troubles is a sense of insecurity.
What would you say was the **root cause** of the problem?
His fears of loneliness lay at the very root of his inability to leave.
I expect money is at the root of the matter.
I've spent months trying to get to the root of the problem.
They consider globalization to be the root of all evil.

definitions.definition: the origin or basis of something

examples.text: Flamenco may have its roots in Arabic music.
The festival has ancient and deep roots in English culture.
Her last three albums have seen her return to her bluegrass roots
We wanted to remain true to our creative roots.
The two languages share a common root.
Jazz's roots are firmly planted in African tradition.
The custom has its roots in Wales.
This shameful treatment struck at the very roots of their human dignity.
The unrest has roots in religious differences.
They can trace their roots back to the 16th century.

definitions.definition: the feelings or connections that you have with a place because you have lived there or your family came from there

examples.text: I'm proud of my Italian roots.
After 20 years in America, I still feel my roots are in England.
We have made lifelong friendships and put down roots.
My husband wants to go back to his Irish roots.
severed from our cultural roots by industrialization

definitions.definition: the part of a word that has the main meaning and that its other forms are based on; a word that other words are formed from

examples.text: ‘Comfort’ is the root of ‘comfortable’, ‘comfortably’, ‘discomfort’ and ‘uncomfortable’.

definitions.definition: a quantity which, when multiplied by itself a particular number of times, produces another quantity
to settle and live in one place

examples.text: After ten years travelling the world, she felt it was time to put down roots somewhere.
We haven't been here long enough to put down roots.

definitions.definition: completely and in a way that affects every part of something

examples.text: The government set out to destroy the organization root and branch.
root-and-branch reforms
I hope those cuttings will take root.
Fortunately, militarism failed to take root in Europe as a whole.

wordOrigin: noun late Old English rōt, from Old Norse rót; related to Latin radix.
